content.question: Let <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be the region in the first quadrant bounded by the graphs of <math alttext="y equals, 1 minus, x cubed " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>−</mo><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="y equals, 1 minus x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>−</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, as shown in the figure above. The region <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the base of a solid. For the solid, each cross section perpendicular to the <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-axis is a square. What is the volume of the solid?

topic.text: 8.7: Volumes with Cross Sections - Squares and Rectangles

skill.text: Skill 3.D: Apply an appropriate mathematical definition, theorem, or test.
